title: Autofill protection only lasting if you actively play multiple games at a time.
body:
After you play a game of either support or get autofilled you generally get a few games of protection, ONLY IF you keep playing afterwards.

I do not get a chance to play too many games in a row due to other responsibilities and it gets a bit frustrating having autofill enabled straight away every day when the previous night (which is usually 1-2 games) I have played an autofilled match but the protection is not there.

I have no problem with autofill in general, but I think that the protection after you play an autofill game should roll into your next X amount of games regardless as to whether you play your next games straight away or another day.

**TLDR: Autofill protection only lasts the X amount of games if you stay logged in and continue to play. It should last for X amount of games regardless as to when you play your next games.**

So what? If you wish to take advantage of your earned autofill protection then you may have to wait longer. If you prefer not to wait then you can fill. The point is that you "earned" the autofill protection. 
The biggest bonus to this would be supports would be a desired duo partner and get more recognition as being team players rather than a role everyone hates being filled to for the second time in a row because you earned protection on your last/only game of the night. 
3.50 isnt very long for an estimated queue time and yet they already activate autofill. I have been autofilled after about 40 seconds. I am willing to wait a lot longer than that for a role i enjoy playing.
There are plenty of people willing to wait longer than this to get the role they want without having to then choose between playing a long game in a role they are unfamiliar with while stuck in lane with a random who might want to play the game totally different and be uncompromising, or dodging and losing LP and getting a delay for their next game. 
In the long run there would likely be more support mains and people would round on anyone who dared abuse them because they want support mains to enjoy the game rather than seeing supports as a hated role that people get filled to coz its just their job to be the teams bltch and buy the items no one else wants to like sightstone and pinks. 
I hope this has elucidated the matter for you.

It hasn't cleared the matter for me at all.

All you have done is provided a theory. Putting it into practice would create longer que times (That you have eluded to and are prepared to wait longer for), but is the whole community? 

Sure they might be, but what is an acceptable length of time?  I won't even mention the low pool of players at off peek times. 

I'm confident riot would have already looked into it and it not been able to ensure that your theory is feasible.

Having no autofill protection is like running out of condoms.

You want to go in but the risk...

All the guy is saying is that he opens his drawer and finds he's out more often then he likes.

He doesn't mind waiting for a new box to arrive if it means he can have some safe fun.

But you're telling him that he should just get in there so that everyone has a chance to enjoy.

Well he doesn't enjoy going to war without a helmet. And that's perfectly alright, it's his business after all.

As I stated before, I have been auto filled in a queue that popped in under 1 min. Some players might think this is great but there seems to be a substantial portion of the community who disagrees, like I do. We are not talking about a game that only goes for a few mins. When you queue for a game of league you have to be willing to set aside in excess of 1 hour, a few mins for queue, a few mins for champ selection, a few mins for loading and then anywhere upwards of 20 mins for a game ( very rarely you see a game go less than 20 mins but often they will go for >30). 

"Thats my point, the waiting to find the autofill. It would be much much longer if they saved the allocated roles of a summoner until he she next logs on. eventually you would end up with a small percentage of auto fills over the majority."

You are proposing a theory that this would result in less autofills which I totally agree with. 
My theory is that in response to this, the community would quickly adapt and see an increase in the roles that people are not currently playing, for the reason they want to get into a game faster, and as less supports in particular would be throwing tantrums about being autofilled which would result in a healthier and happier community.

And the "I dont want to autofill" button could have a timeout of say 10 mins or so which is generally around the time people start getting pretty antsy about the delay, or have the game prioritise people who dont use the button over people that do in matchmaking, or have some very small reward for people who fill or main support, and potentially disable it at very, very off peak times, but not anywhere as readily as it is right now.

Right now there are many games with people throwing tantrums about getting filled and making all sorts of threats of feeding etc in champion select if people wont swap, picking troll sups and taking farm, not buying any sup items and not even trying to ward, basically just playing mid or top stuck in a lane with someone else who they ignore or troll. Chat logs from lobby dont seem to be recorded so they can make all sorts of toxic threats and hurl abuse around and then just go silent in game and troll away and as long as they dont actually feed or abuse anyone in the game they get off scot free. 

My point is, autofill in lower elo seems to be much more counter productive than helpful a lot of the time. In high elo with a much smaller pool people recognize each other and generally work together to create a team with the best chance at winning but in lower elo it just seems to encourage more trouble than it solves. If the queue is popping within a few mins and people are getting autofilled then I dont think it is doing its job properly.
